title: Takeover twist in trigger for CEO's million-dollar bonus
text:
Collection House’s new plan cites a change of control event occurring when someone acquires 25 per cent of the company.

The last plan Collection House shareholders approved in 2016 defined a “change of control” event as being a takeover bid, and specified the bidder acquiring more than 50 per cent of company shares. The board also could declare “any similar event” as a change of control, under that plan.

Insurance-banking giant Suncorp’s share performance plan also defines a change of control event as occurring at 50 per cent.

More discretion for the board

Asked why a change had occurred, Collection House chairman Leigh Berkley said in a statement the 25 per cent ownership change marked “additional discretion” for the board.

“The default position remains that if the board does not exercise its discretion, upon a 50.01 per cent change of control, unvested rights will automatically vest and any trading restrictions will cease to apply,” he said.

“This is aligned with the Corporations Act provisions relating to takeover bids which are generally triggered when more than 20 per cent of the voting shares in a company are proposed to be purchased by a prospective bidder.”

The change comes after Collection House chief executive Anthony Rivas in September exercised 1 million performance rights under the old plan, worth $1.24 a share each.

Advertisement

That had required Collection House meeting targets linked to compound annual growth, starting at exceeding 5 per cent in earnings per share over three years.

Collection House had met that target but only with an accounting change boosting the latest financial results. Analysts had determined that Collection House’s earnings would have actually gone backwards without the accounting change.

Mr Rivas had, however, earlier voluntarily foregone 2 million in performance rights.

The new performance rights are different in that they incorporate more than just EPS targets of growth of at least 5 per cent each year to 2020. This time almost 40 per cent of the performance rights are linked to “non-financial” hurdles such as customer and staff engagement.

Mr Berkley told The Australian Financial Review that Collection House “does not anticipate any significant accounting changes for the sector in the short to medium”. The last accounting change was mandated and any further differences would “be evaluated by the board”, he said.

These changes were sparked after taking advice from consultants and adopted some recommendations from the financial services royal commission, he said.

“While the royal commission recommendations are primarily directed to the banking, insurance and superannuation industries, Collection House believes some of the principles also hold true for its industry,” he said.
description: A new bonus plan says someone buying 25 per cent of a company could constitute a "change of control".
